Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern the universe and is the force that gives weight to physical objects. It is an attractive force that exists between all things with mass or energy. The force of gravity pulls objects towards each other, and its strength depends on the mass of the objects involved. Gravity is relatively weak compared to the other fundamental forces—the strong and weak nuclear forces and electromagnetism—but it has an infinite range. This means that gravity is always influencing physical matter, although its effects become weaker as objects move farther apart. 

On Earth, gravity gives weight to physical objects and is what makes things fall when dropped. It also governs the movements of celestial bodies, controlling the orbits of planets, moons, and stars. Gravity is a crucial element in holding galaxies together and even shapes the universe on the largest scales.

Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces that govern the universe and can be defined as the attractive force by which a world or other body draws objects toward its center. The force of gravity is determined by the mass of the objects and the distance between them. 

The most well-known effect of gravity is the relationship between the Earth and objects on its surface. The Earth's gravity pulls objects downward, which we perceive as weight. The force of gravity varies depending on the position and mass of the objects involved. For example, the gravity of the Moon and the Sun also affect the Earth and the tides in the oceans. 

Gravity is a crucial element in maintaining the structure of the universe and has a significant influence on the formation and shape of celestial bodies. It is also what gives inertia to objects, influencing their motion through space and time.

However, its influence becomes significant when dealing with everyday objects and astronomical bodies. The force of gravity on an object depends on its mass and the mass of anything else nearby. Gravity is described by the general theory of relativity proposed by Albert Einstein. The theory describes gravity not as a force, but as the result of the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy. This curvature makes it possible for us to experience gravity's effects, such as when a ball is thrown upwards, it appears to us that gravity is pulling it down.

Despite being the weakest force, gravity has the longest range. It operates on all scales: from the tiniest subatomic particles to entire galaxies. Scientists and astronomers use the principles of gravity to predict the movements of celestial bodies and send probes and missions to them.

However, Newton's theory has since been superseded by Einstein's general theory of relativity, which describes gravity as the result of the curvature of spacetime caused by the presence of mass and energy. According to relativity, gravity is not a force, but rather a geometric property of spacetime.

The strength of gravity depends on the mass of the objects involved and the distance between them. It increases with mass and decreases with the square of the distance, controlling the motion of celestial bodies, stars, galaxies, and even light! Yes, gravity can bend the path of light.

Everything falls at the same rate, regardless of mass, which is about 9.8 meters per second squared.
